awd_titl_txt: Great Ape Juvenile Development and Digestive Physiology
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans and many non-human primate species have long periods of juvenile development, but the evolutionary underpinnings of these patterns are not fully understood. Orangutans (Pongo pygmaeus), which have a slow life history and extreme fluctuations in their food supply, are a good species for testing hypotheses about factors that may favor slow juvenile development during evolution. In this project, multiple methodologies will be applied in a long-term study of orangutans in Gunung Palung National Park, Indonesia, to determine how food availability affects juvenile growth and development, and the extent to which juvenile and adult orangutans differ in foraging behaviors, diets, and overall ability to extract energy from foods. The project provides research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and increases scientific capacity near the research site. The project runs parallel to the principal investigator's conservation program that helps conserve orangutans through education, alternative livelihoods, adoption of customary forests, and sharing of research with local authorities. Using social media, website, Facebook, twitter, monthly newsletter, and weekly radio programs, the project educates local and world-wide audiences about the importance of orangutan conservation and the application of research to solving conservation problems. The project team members also will develop a special Girl Scout patch program to teach skills related to scientific leadership, field biology and the study of animals to girls in the upper elementary/middle school range, the highest risk group of children for dropping out of STEM subjects.  

Understanding what constrains juvenile development and the ability of the growing organism to translate energy into growth and maintenance, before the onset of reproduction, is central to our understanding of animal life history, including the study of human evolution. It has been argued that human evolution has been marked by selection for a slower life history. Existing comparative data on great ape development are limited, and based primarily on captive animals living in energy-rich environment, thus likely experiencing accelerated growth. This study sheds light on the concept of ecological risk aversion by looking at both developmental and ecological influences on digestion. The investigators will use behavioral observation, physiological measures, and data on diet and available food resources to determine: 1) if juvenile orangutans are at greater ecological risk than adults, whether juveniles are able to extract less energy from their food, the role of masticatory force in breaking up food into smaller particles, and how body size determines gut passage rates and how much energy is extracted from food; 2) how juveniles and adults differ in their foraging behavior, diet composition and overall energy expenditure; 3) how juvenile development impacts maternal behavior and physiology; 4) at what rate juvenile orangutans grow and whether this differs depending on food availability; and 5) how juvenile orangutan physiology changes with development and depends on food energy intake. If digestion is impeded when consuming high fiber fallback foods during periods of poor food availability, we can better understand the compensatory behaviors that both juveniles and their mothers take to offset caloric and nutrient deficiency. Because of their smaller body size, incomplete gut biome, and masticatory immaturity, juveniles are predicted to be more vulnerable to periods of food shortage. Additionally, if larger-bodied animals of the same species are able to process fiber more efficiently than smaller-bodied animals, this has could have implications for how the evolution of body size impacts the ability to achieve a higher quality diet.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how pre-reproductive juveniles translate energy into growth and maintenance is central to our understanding of animal life history. Some hypothesize that slower life history was selected for during human evolution, but evaluation requires contextualizing human development with other great apes. Orangutans? (Pongo pygmaeus) extended life history with extreme fluctuations in their food supply provide an excellent opportunity to study evolutionary pressures selecting for slow juvenile growth and development.

To do this, we applied new technologies to long-term research in Gunung Palung National Park, Indonesia, yielding new insights into orangutan life history. Our objectives were to understand 1) whether juveniles face greater starvation risk than adults through examining nutritional intake, whether juveniles extract less energy from their food, the role of masticatory force in breaking food into smaller particles, and relationships between body size, gut passage, and extracting energy from food 2) How juveniles and adults differ in foraging behavior, diet composition and energy expenditure 3) How juvenile development impacts maternal behavior and physiology 4) how juvenile orangutan growth and physiology develop and relates to food availability and energy intake. 

To accomplish this, we conducted 1690 follows, totaling 17160 hours, of 169 wild orangutans. From these follows, we measured food intake during 8472 feeding bouts. We collected 1618 fecal samples from 82 individuals to study digestion through gut passage rate, fecal particle size and fiber digestion. Fecal samples were also used for genetic determination, fecal temperature measurements, and microbiome and intestinal parasite analysis. We measured food availability with monthly monitoring of over 11,000 trees and lianas and food samples collected from 4555 trees. We collected 582 urine samples from 54 individuals to measure fluctuating hormonal levels associated with energetic status. We analyzed locomotion, food sharing, body position, and travel distance from behavioral follows, and nursing, food oral processing, and clinging behavior from 1028 videos. We measured growth rates from 253 laser camera photos.

We discovered that juvenile digestive efficiency likely constrains growth, development, and survivorship during periods of low food availability when orangutan diets are fiber-enriched. We analyzed fecal fiber content from mother-offspring pairs, demonstrating that offspring consistently digest 50% less fiber than their mothers. We also demonstrated that juvenile digestive efficiency is significantly lower than flanged males, reflecting potential constraints of small body size and inferior hindgut digestion. We found that juvenile orangutans are less efficient at processing food items than adults, requiring more canine and post-canine chews to process the same food category. We also demonstrated that infant orangutans (under 2) almost never travel independently, but by the age of 4 they travel independently over the same distance and proportion of time as their mothers, suggesting that this period is critical for developing the ability to navigate the forest. We demonstrated that maternal behavior and activity patterns, including time spent resting, foraging, and traveling, are influenced by offspring presence and age, and that nursing offspring have consistently higher δ15N values, reflecting milk consumption.

Through this project we developed new methodologies and scientific infrastructure. We expanded analytical capabilities of our nutritional laboratory at Boston University to include free simple sugars, tannins, and fiber and tested creatinine assays of urine. We developed new methodologies for measuring fecal temperature. We expanded our field lab capabilities to process fecal samples and published a paper on building field labs for conservation. We developed a cost-effective, user-friendly laser camera and methodology to measure arboreal animals.

The project met our broader impact goals. We provided research and training to 25 Boston University undergraduates, 38 Indonesian undergraduates, 10 graduate students, 2 postdoctoral fellows, 1 high school student, 2 master?s level research managers, 4 post-BA managers, 6 non-student research assistants, and 14 Indonesian field and lab assistants. We shared results in four scientific publications, 3 in-review publications, 63 newsletter articles, and 4 PhD dissertations. We made 70 scientific presentations at 23 international conferences and gave over 20 invited talks. Through the Gunung Palung Orangutan Conservation Program, we contributed to conservation efforts in the communities surrounding GPNP including environmental education, conservation awareness, capacity building, endangered animal protection, and alternative livelihood development. We provided data to Indonesian authorities on orangutan population density and distribution, health status, and forest condition; researchers gave 112 presentations to the National Park.

Our team of 10 female scientists (undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and the PI) developed a Girl Scout Field Biology patch and ran a Field Biology Encampment in 2018 for over 80 girls and 20 adults. Through hands-on activities girls learned about using compasses and navigating forests, observing primate behavior, setting up plots to measure tree diversity, and devising conservation solutions. For each module, materials were developed for 4 age groups from kindergarten through 12th grade and separate adult leader trainings were held. We also made these instructional materials for the Girl Scout Field Biology patch available to girls from diverse communities.
